awd_titl_txt: RAPID: Invasion of Geoengineering Earthworms in Alaska: Extents, Mechanisms, and Impacts
awd_abstract_narration:
Almost all of Earth's northern biomes have evolved in the absence of earthworms since the last glacial maximum. This status quo is rapidly changing, however, due to advancing human disturbances and land use changes in the cold regions of the world. Invasive European earthworms are now beginning to appear at the edge of Alaskan permafrost. Among these invasive earthworms, geoengineering earthworms include species that physically disturb soil environments. Invasion of geoengineering earthworms is an irreversible process resulting in rapid deterioration of ecosystem functions including soil carbon and nutrient cycling and reduction of floral and faunal biodiversity. Early intervention is key, and it is urgent to establish the underlying scientific knowledge of earthworm invasion in Alaska. Here the principal investigator proposes to conduct rapid assessments of the distribution and primary introduction mechanisms of exotic earthworms across diverse ecoregions in Alaska. This research will also reveal the extents that the invasive earthworms, where present, disturb boreal and tundra soils in Alaska. By collaborating with Kenai National Wildlife Refuge, Agricultural Extension Station of the University of Alaska, Fairbanks, and the University of Alaska Museum, the investigator will leverage this RAPID project as a way to facilitate agency-, public-, and policy-level actions to stop earthworm invasion in Alaska in its infancy - before it is too late to act.

The vast boreal forests and tundra of Alaska are increasingly threatened by ongoing climate change. Global scale climate impacts on soil biogeochemistry can, however, be substantially accelerated by increasing introductions of exotic European geoengineering earthworms. The project goal is to (1) urgently prepare research community for this upcoming change and (2) facilitate early intervention to stop earthworm invasion in Alaska. The investigator seeks to test the following hypotheses: 1) human introduction (not climate conditions) primarily limits the current earthworm distribution in Alaska; 2) impacts of exotic geoengineering earthworms on Alaskan soils are more dramatic than those reported for the formerly glaciated temperate forests in the contiguous U.S.; 3) species composition of exotic geoengineering earthworms differs by human introduction mechanisms in Alaska; and 4)  earthworms' ability to invade into boreal and tundra depend on their population compositions. To test the hypotheses, the investigator will examine earthworm populations and their impacts on soils at the interfaces between human-disturbed areas and the surrounding natural vegetation at field sites that reflect the major eco-regions and range of climate conditions including extents of permafrost in Alaska. This RAPID project will contribute to advancing science by newly highlighting the vulnerability of the Alaskan Arctic to the combination of both human land use changes and climate change. In addition to peer-reviewed publications, the investigator will publish a booklet that helps land managers and citizens to identify exotic geoengineering earthworms on their properties and assess their impacts on the natural vegetation and soils in Alaska. Collected earthworm specimens will be archived in the University of Alaska Museum, and specimen-specific information will be published online through the Museum's database for the broader scientific community and the public.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
We typically think of earthworms as the symbol of healthy soils, and we believe that they may be found anywhere there are plants. But are they really? If we go back 10,000 years, much of the northern hemisphere was covered in thick ice, which wiped out native earthworms. The glacier melted away as the earth warmed, and vegetation followed. Earthworms, on the other hand, were unable to keep up. Earthworms, being a slow organism, may have only traveled roughly 60 miles (100 km) since the last glacier. As a result, enormous forests, prairies, and tundra have formed throughout North America and Eurasia without earthworms. This status quo was drastically disrupted when increasingly globalized human activities accelerated the spread of earthworms.


This NSF-funded project is the first to systematically map invasive European earthworms in Alaska. The University of Minnesota team conducted earthworm surveys in Juneau, the Kenai Peninsula, Matanuska Valley, and Anchorage, Nome on the Seward Peninsula, interior Alaska near Fairbanks and Delta Junction, and ultimately along the Dalton Highway. The survey focused specifically on geoengineering earthworms, which are capable of physically mixing and perturbing soils as they cause cascading effects that significantly modify soils, plants, and nutrient flows.

The prevalence of geoengineering earthworms is dependent on human introduction in areas where the climate is relatively milder and human activity is concentrated (e.g., Juneau, Kenai Peninsula, Matanuska Valley, and Anchorage). The presence of geoengineering earthworms is, while sporadic, always related with human activities such as recreational fishing, gardening, and home developments. The number of geoengineering earthworms decreases with increasing distance from the introduction sources, and the research team discovered that soils undergo drastic changes as the population of geoengineering earthworms increases. Geoengineering earthworms, without exception, remove the dense litter layer typical of boreal forests in Alaska and replace it with mineral-rich topsoil. The abrupt transformation takes place in less than 5 years. The climate places the first limitation on the European invasive earthworms in inner Alaska, Seward Peninsula, and along the Dalton Highway, where the climate is significantly colder. Regardless of whether geoengineering earthworms are introduced by humans, their existence is limited to geothermal areas or farms where the mix of plowing and microclimate conditions results in locally warm soils.

Human cultures have a significant impact on the proliferation of invasive European earthworms and the species composition in Alaska. Gardening is popular. Many homeowners and gardeners have made deliberate efforts to bring earthworms into their gardens in the hopes of improving their soils, but their success or failure is largely dependent on the climate. Although those gardeners' efforts along the Dalton Highway above the Arctic Circle have not been successful, success may come soon due to continued climate warming, with the resulting disruption of ecological processes in the surrounding forests and tundra. Recreational fishing is also important. Recreational anglers who purchase and utilize live earthworm baits frequent inland lakes and streams. In Matanuska Valley and Kenai, many lake boat launching places and lake shore forests are densely populated by nightcrawlers, a favorite fishing bait available at bait shops and Walmart. Surprisingly, regardless of the amount of recreational fishing, nightcrawlers are scarce along the coastal forests because coastal fishing uses salmon eggs rather than earthworms as bait. These findings emphasize the significance of what humans do in spreading and controlling invasive European earthworms in Alaska.

These discoveries are critical for the future of Alaska which is sometimes labeled the last frontier. Because of the rapid warming in the high latitudes, human-introduced earthworms will become increasingly able to survive and penetrate forests and tundra. More coastal communities will be created, and more people will migrate in, as the arctic route opens up for increasing marine trade. People will want to cultivate and produce food locally. Alongside imported topsoil, mulch, compost, bulb plants, and horticultural and crop plants with roots, invasive earthworms and their cocoons will arrive. Wild Alaska will continue to entice recreational anglers who want to toss their fishing rods for nightcrawlers. Outreach and education are crucial to reducing the spread of invasive earthworms in Alaska, and these efforts should focus on gardeners, homeowners, and recreational fisherman. During fieldwork, the research team worked closely with agricultural extension agents at the University of Alaska, Fairbanks, and many gardeners volunteered to help with earthworm surveys and learn about their harmful impacts on boreal forests. Biologists from the Kenai National Wildlife Refuge collaborated with the team by presenting some of the findings at the MatSu Salmon Symposium to reach out to recreational anglers. As the project's findings are published, the outreach and education initiatives will further expand.
